title: The UK government channels its inner SoftBank
text:
Rishi Sunak's Silicon vision

What do a vegan foodmaker, the Secret Cinema chain, and a mobile beauty service have in common?

They're all backed by UK taxpayers. Yes, really.

These are just a few of the more than 150 British start-ups the British public now has a stake in after loans taken out by largely lossmaking companies as part of a Covid relief programme converted into equity stakes.

A brief explainer: the £1.1bn Future Fund, launched by the UK Treasury in May last year, offered loans to start-ups that couldn't access other support schemes, in many cases because they had yet to turn a profit. 

Start-ups that borrowed from the scheme were required to match their loans with private investment, which would convert into equity stakes at the next funding round unless repaid.

The programme offered loans from £125,000 to £5m, with a minimum of 8 per cent interest that accrues until the loan is either repaid or turns into government equity at a discount.

Almost 18 months later, many of those borrowers have been unable to repay their loans, making chancellor Rishi Sunak one of the UK's most voracious venture capitalists by default.

Sunak spent a decade working in the financial sector before transitioning to politics — first as an analyst at Goldman Sachs and then at TCI, the UK activist fund run by hedge fund billionaire Chris Hohn, and its spin-off Theleme Partners.

DD readers are no stranger to big crazy punts on little-known, lossmaking start-ups. Think about the puzzling array of bets spearheaded by SoftBank's Vision Fund and the scrutiny drawn by the company's highly competitive, instinct-driven investment culture.

But Masayoshi Son's eclectic portfolio looks mild compared to the collection of taxpayer stakes amassed by Sunak: from a trendy cinema chain and a kombucha-based drinks brewer to the car-selling site Motorway.co.uk and Snoop, the banking app founded by former Virgin Money boss Jayne-Anne Gadhia.

The 158 companies that now count UK taxpayers as shareholders are just the ones disclosed by the government so far. Almost 1,200 businesses took out loans from the programme, likely leaving the chancellor with stakes in hundreds more companies.

This isn't the first time UK taxpayer money has been invested in a struggling start-up. 

In an acquisition orchestrated by Boris Johnson's former chief adviser Dominic Cummings last year, the UK spent about £500m of taxpayers' money to rescue the failed satellite operator OneWeb from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in a joint investment with Indian telecoms tycoon Sunil Bharti Mittal.

And the government's ambitions to grow its start-up scene have never been stronger, as investors hunt for UK “unicorns” with the potential to take on the trillion-dollar tech companies of China and Silicon Valley that have historically dwarfed British business.

Evergrande's default domino effect

Last week we told you about the deepening liquidity crisis at Chinese real estate giant Evergrande. 

The situation took another turn for the worse this week after retail investors descended upon the company's headquarters in Shenzhen.

Footage circulating on social media showed investors, who had bought wealth management products related to Evergrande, demanding their money back.

When it comes to the world's most indebted property developer, which has Rmb572bn ($89bn) in debts but close to Rmb2tn ($310bn) in liabilities, there's a long list of people with money at stake. 

A potential failure would hit not only its creditors, but the contractors that help build and sell its apartments and the customers who have already bought them. It has ongoing projects in hundreds of Chinese cities.

On Tuesday, Evergrande said it expects worsening sales in September, and added that subsidiaries had failed to “discharge their guarantee obligations as scheduled” for third-party wealth management products worth Rmb934m. The company also warned of a “cross-default” if it fails to meet its financial obligations.

“The company is in active discussion with the issuers and investors with a view to reaching a mutually agreeable repayment arrangement,” it said.

Fears over a default have already rippled over to other developers in China, the fiasco exposing the perilous state of China's vast property sector. 

The property developer has also borrowed heavily on international markets where it owes about $14bn, meaning the repercussions could soon be felt beyond China's borders.

Are junior bankers being replaced by robots?

Entry-level analysts needn't fret over their six-figure salaries just yet.

As record dealmaking activity wreaked havoc on the work/life balances of Wall Street's lower ranks — the effect of gruelling hours on the mental health of a group of first-year Goldman Sachs staff was captured in a now infamous PowerPoint — banks are starting to rethink things.

Companies including Goldman, Barclays and Moelis are working on initiatives to automate basic functions such as generating pitch books and valuation modelling — aka “grunt work” — with the aim of reducing workloads and retaining talent, executives told the FT's Joshua Franklin.

The efforts hint that juicy pay raises across the industry haven't been enough to stem the industry's high turnover, and that, even in the middle of an M&A windfall, understaffing still persists.

Automating less glamorous tasks isn't a one-size-fits all solution, however. As Lex points out, the average managing director has a limited understanding of how said technology works, potentially burdening their subordinates with even more work.

“Some [bankers] only spend time with junior bankers when they've made a mistake,” said David Stowell, a finance professor at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management and a former investment banker. “Then these young people feel like they've been treated like machines.”

Job moves

  • Goldman Sachs has appointed Denis Coleman, currently co-head of its financing group, as its chief financial officer, succeeding Stephen Scherr, who will retire at the end of January.

  • Deutsche Bank has hired Lewis Burnett as head of UK corporate broking. He was previously co-head of corporate broking at BNP Paribas.

  • Private equity firm One Rock Capital Partners has hired Allison Spector as head of ESG. She joins in New York from Nuveen, where she led sustainability initiatives for the firm's real assets and private markets groups. 

  • Daniel Michael, who recently stepped down as chief of the complex financial instruments unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of enforcement, is joining Skadden as a partner in the firm's New York office.

  • Jones Day has hired Dorothy Giobbe as of counsel in its financial markets practice, based in New York. She was previously an executive director and assistant general counsel at JPMorgan Chase.
